status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

issuetype.description: A new feature of the product, which has yet to be developed.
issuetype.name: New Feature

resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

   @AlenkaF Please can you review this and let me know if this is the kind of thing you'd like in this section or if you'd prefer I add more detail?

AlenkaF commented on pull request #12119:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/12119#issuecomment-1010001310


   @thisisnic I think it is great! Good intro to the main part of the documentation.
   
   I did get an idea when looking at this PR to move notes about [recompiling cython, C++ ](https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/master/docs/source/developers/guide/step_by_step/testing.rst) from testing section to this part of the guide. I think it fits better. And then a sentence or two could be added for the R package, that it needs no recompiling (if I understand correctly).
   
   What do you think? I could try to push a commit with the suggestion here?


-- 
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.

thisisnic commented on pull request #12119:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/12119#issuecomment-1010043935


   > @thisisnic I think it is great! Good intro to the main part of the documentation.
   > 
   > I did get an idea when looking at this PR to move notes about [recompiling cython, C++ ](https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/master/docs/source/developers/guide/step_by_step/testing.rst) from testing section to this part of the guide. I think it fits better. And then a sentence or two could be added for the R package, that it needs no recompiling (if I understand correctly).
   > 
   > What do you think? I could try to push a commit with the suggestion here?
   
   I think it makes more sense here, though you could always mention it in both places if it fits in both? Maybe here could be the detailed version, and in the testing section you just briefly remind the reader they should recompile?


--

thisisnic edited a comment on pull request #12119:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/12119#issuecomment-1010043935


   > @thisisnic I think it is great! Good intro to the main part of the documentation.
   > 
   > I did get an idea when looking at this PR to move notes about [recompiling cython, C++ ](https://github.com/apache/arrow/blob/master/docs/source/developers/guide/step_by_step/testing.rst) from testing section to this part of the guide. I think it fits better. And then a sentence or two could be added for the R package, that it needs no recompiling (if I understand correctly).
   > 
   > What do you think? I could try to push a commit with the suggestion here?
   
   I think it makes more sense here, though you could always mention it in both places if it fits in both? Maybe here could be the detailed version, and in the testing section you just briefly remind the reader they should recompile?
   
   Might be easier to have it as a separate PR - up to you!


--

dragosmg commented on a change in pull request #12119:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/12119#discussion_r782269957



##########
File path: docs/source/developers/guide/step_by_step/building.rst
##########
@@ -150,5 +150,13 @@ interested to find more information.
 
          - :ref:`build_pyarrow_win`
 
-   .. tab:: Building the R package
 
+   .. tab:: Building the R package
+      
+	  When working on code in the R package, you only need to build the Arrow C++ 
+	  library (often referred to in the R documentation as 'libarrow') from source 
+	  if you wish to make changes to the code there; otherwise you can install a 
+	  binary version of the C++ libary and then need to link it up with the R package.

Review comment:
       I think this still doesn't work - installing `libarrow` from homebrew (on Mac) and having only the R package as `source`. 




--

thisisnic commented on a change in pull request #12119:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/12119#discussion_r782271539



##########
File path: docs/source/developers/guide/step_by_step/building.rst
##########
@@ -150,5 +150,13 @@ interested to find more information.
 
          - :ref:`build_pyarrow_win`
 
-   .. tab:: Building the R package
 
+   .. tab:: Building the R package
+      
+	  When working on code in the R package, you only need to build the Arrow C++ 
+	  library (often referred to in the R documentation as 'libarrow') from source 
+	  if you wish to make changes to the code there; otherwise you can install a 
+	  binary version of the C++ libary and then need to link it up with the R package.

Review comment:
       Great point, will update




--

fields.description:
*Building R-Arrow* section of the Steps in making your first PR.

Steps in making your first PR outline:
 * Set up (command line and Git)
 * Building Arrow package
 ** Building C++
 ** Building PyArrow
 ** Building R package
 * Finding good first issues
 * Solving the problem
 ** Python bindings
 ** R bindings
 * Testing
 * Life cycle of a Pull Request
 ** Making the PR
 ** Reviews and get the PR merge
fields.summary: [Doc] Steps in making your first PR - building R package
